CE 5362 Surface Water Modeling

Prerequesite:CE 5360 or instructor consent
Theory and application of hydrodynamic models. Theory and application of watershed models.

The course trains engineers to practice hydrologic and hydraulic modeling in one-dimensional unsteady conditions; and in higher sparial dimensions (2D/3D) using custom-written and professional software tools. Integration of simulation tools to examine complex systems is emphasized. The course provides an experience in different modeling platforms(DIY, HEC-RAS, SWMM, EFDC) to answer hydrodynamic questions using non-trivial examples. Upon successful completion of this course, the participant will have:

1. Reviewed theory for computational hydraulics

  • Develop and code a Lax-Diffusion method for time-varying flow in an open channel
  • Compare Lax-Diffusion model with SWMM.


    • 2. Simulate a Branched (Tribuitary) type system

  • Simulate the confluence of two streams in steady conditions using SWMM
  • Simulate the confluence of two streams in unsteady conditions using SWMM
  • Simulate the confluence of White Oak and Buffalo Bayou using SWMM
  • Simulate a large-scale (county) drainage network


    • 3. Applied Interconnected Channel and Pond Routing (ICPR) approximation for 2D estuary/floodplain modeling

  • Simulate a subdivision scale watershed using SWMM


    • 4. Simulate constituient transport in a surface water system

  • Simulate effects of Green Infrastructure (GI) Components in a surface water system


    • Additional Optional Topics (as time permits)

  • Develop and code a diffusion approximation for 2D floodplain
  • Develop and code a Boltzman-Lattice model for 2D estuary flow
  • Simulate selected examples using EFDC or SToRM

    • CE 5360 Graduate students status (exceptional undergraduates by instructor permission). Additionally students are expectied to have had courses equivalent to a university course in fluid mechanics, hydrology, environmental engineering (or science). Familarity with computer programming (MatLab, Python, Excel-VBA, R) will be useful.

    DIY codes using JupyterLab/iPython

    Simulation models will use SWMM, SToRM and/or EFDC (or other 2D/3D code)
